Second, they could opt for a pro-rata allotment, distributing shares proportionally to all applicants and adjusting excess application money towards allotment or subsequent calls. questions.answer: The limited liability feature of a company means that the personal assets of Neil and Kanishq, as shareholders, are protected. Their liability is restricted to the unpaid amount of shares they hold. If KnowledgeCompass faces financial difficulties or goes into liquidation, their personal wealth (e.g., homes, savings) would not be at risk to pay off company debts. This provides significant protection to the founders and other investors, making investment in KnowledgeCompass less risky and encouraging capital contribution without fear of losing everything.

The company would typically debit a 'Calls in Arrears Account' and credit the respective 'Share Call Account.' According to Table F of the Companies Act, if the Articles of Association are silent, KnowledgeCompass could charge interest on these arrears at a rate not exceeding 10% per annum from the due date until payment. questions.answer: Forfeiture is the cancellation of shares due to non-payment of calls. It allows KnowledgeCompass to reclaim shares from defaulting shareholders and reallocate them, ensuring the full capital is raised. Reissue allows the company to sell these forfeited shares to new investors, often at a discount, but importantly, the discount cannot exceed the amount originally received on those shares. Any profit made on reissue (amount received on forfeiture + reissue price - face value) is a capital profit transferred to the Capital Reserve, strengthening the company's financial position. This process helps KnowledgeCompass recover lost capital and maintain its shareholder base.

The excess amount, the 'premium,' is credited to the 'Securities Premium Account.' This amount is not distributable as normal dividends but can be used for specific purposes, such as issuing fully paid bonus shares, writing off preliminary expenses, writing off share issue expenses/commission, or paying premium on redemption of preference shares/debentures, or buyback of shares. shortAnswer2.answer: Limited liability means that the financial responsibility of the company's members (shareholders) is limited to the extent of the unpaid amount on the shares they hold. If a shareholder has paid the full nominal value of shares, they are not liable for any further debts of the company, even if the company faces financial difficulties. This protects the personal assets of the shareholders, making investment less risky.

shortAnswer2.answer: When a shareholder fails to pay the amount due on allotment or any call, such an amount is termed 'Calls in Arrears'. If the company maintains a separate Calls in Arrears Account, it is debited. The company's Articles of Association, or Table F, may allow charging interest (e.g., up to 10% p.a.) on these unpaid amounts from the due date until actual payment. This helps the company recover dues and ensures financial discipline.

shortAnswer2.answer: In a pro-rata allotment, shares are allotted proportionately to all applicants, especially in cases of oversubscription. The excess application money received from applicants is not refunded but is adjusted first towards the amount due on allotment. If any excess still remains after adjusting for allotment, it can then be adjusted towards future calls (Calls in Advance) or refunded, depending on the company's policy and Articles of Association. This reduces the immediate cash outflow for the company.

shortAnswer2.answer: Share Forfeiture is the cancellation of shares by a company due to the non-payment of allotment or call money by a shareholder. This action is taken in accordance with the provisions in the company's Articles of Association. The forfeited shares can then be reissued to new shareholders.

shortAnswer2.answer: Authorised Capital is the maximum amount of share capital that a company is legally permitted to issue, as stated in its Memorandum of Association. Issued Capital is that part of the authorised capital which the company actually offers to the public for subscription. Subscribed Capital is the portion of the issued capital that has been actually subscribed or applied for by the public. longAnswerQuestions.answer150Words: Share capital is broadly classified into several categories. 'Authorised Capital' is the maximum amount of capital a company is legally permitted to issue, as stated in its Memorandum of Association. 'Issued Capital' is the portion of authorised capital that the company actually offers to the public or others for subscription. 'Subscribed Capital' refers to the part of the issued capital that has been applied for and agreed to be purchased by the public. 'Called-up Capital' is the amount that the company has formally requested from its shareholders out of the subscribed capital. Finally, 'Paid-up Capital' is the portion of the called-up capital that has been actually received from the shareholders. 'Uncalled Capital' is the part of subscribed capital not yet called, and 'Reserve Capital' is a specific portion of uncalled capital callable only during winding up. These classifications provide clarity on the company's capital structure and its financial status at different stages.
longAnswerQuestions.answer200Words: The share capital of a company is categorized to reflect its legal and financial status. Firstly, 'Authorised Capital' (or Nominal/Registered Capital) is the maximum share capital a company is permitted to issue, as defined in its Memorandum. It sets an upper limit for fundraising. 'Issued Capital' is the portion of authorised capital that the company offers for public subscription. Any part not offered is 'Unissued Capital'. 'Subscribed Capital' is the segment of issued capital actually taken up by investors. If the subscribed shares are fully paid, it's 'Subscribed and Fully Paid-up Capital'; otherwise, it's 'Subscribed but not Fully Paid-up'. 'Called-up Capital' is the amount the company demands from shareholders on subscribed shares, while 'Paid-up Capital' is the actual cash received from shareholders for the called-up amount; any shortfall is 'Calls in Arrears'. Lastly, 'Uncalled Capital' is the balance of subscribed capital not yet called. A company may designate a part of its uncalled capital as 'Reserve Capital', which can only be called upon winding up. These categories are crucial for financial reporting and understanding a company's financial health and fundraising capacity.
longAnswerQuestions.answer50To75Words: Share capital is broadly categorized: Authorised (max allowed), Issued (offered to public), Subscribed (applied for by public), Called-up (demanded by company), and Paid-up (actually received). longAnswerQuestions.answer150Words: A 'share' is a fractional unit into which the total share capital of a company is divided, representing a part of ownership interest. According to the Companies Act, 2013, a company can primarily issue two types of shares: Preference Shares and Equity Shares. Preference Shares carry preferential rights over equity shares regarding dividend payment (fixed amount or rate) and repayment of capital upon the company's winding up. They can be cumulative, non-cumulative, participating, non-participating, redeemable, or irredeemable. Equity Shares are all shares that are not preference shares. They do not have preferential rights but are entitled to the residual profits after preference dividends. Equity shareholders bear higher risk but also have the potential for higher returns and generally possess voting rights, giving them control over the company's management. Both types serve different investor needs and capital-raising objectives.
longAnswerQuestions.answer200Words:
A 'share' represents the smallest unit into which the total share capital of a company is divided. It signifies a fractional ownership interest in the company, entitling the holder (shareholder) to certain rights and obligations. As per the Companies Act, 2013, two primary types of shares can be issued:

1.  **Preference Shares:** These shares carry preferential rights. Firstly, they have a preferential right to receive dividends at a fixed amount or rate before any dividend is paid to equity shareholders. Secondly, in the event of the company's winding up, they have a preferential right to the repayment of capital before equity shareholders. Preference shares can be further classified as cumulative (unpaid dividends accumulate), non-cumulative, participating (share in surplus profits), non-participating, redeemable (repayable by the company), or irredeemable (not repayable during the company's lifetime).

2.  **Equity Shares (or Ordinary Shares):** These are shares that do not possess any preferential rights regarding dividend payment or capital repayment. Equity shareholders are entitled to the distributable profits after preference shareholders have been paid. Dividends on equity shares are not fixed and vary with available profits. Equity shares typically carry voting rights, giving their holders control over the company's management, although shares with differential voting rights can also be issued.
longAnswerQuestions.answer50To75Words: A 'share' is a unit of a company's capital, representing ownership. longAnswerQuestions.answer150Words: In case of oversubscription, where applications exceed shares offered, companies have three main strategies for allotment. Firstly, the directors can 'fully accept some applications and totally reject others,' refunding application money for rejected applications. Secondly, they can make a 'pro-rata allotment' to all applicants, proportionally distributing shares. Here, excess application money is adjusted towards the allotment money due, and any remaining balance might be adjusted against future calls or refunded. Thirdly, a 'combination of the above two' is commonly adopted: rejecting some applications outright while making a pro-rata allotment to the remaining applicants. From an accounting perspective, these situations involve careful transfer of application money to share capital, adjustment to allotment accounts, and refunds to ensure accurate reflection of capital and liabilities.
longAnswerQuestions.answer200Words:
The process for the allotment of shares in case of oversubscription requires careful management, as more applications are received than shares offered. Companies typically adopt one of three methods:

1.  **Full Acceptance and Outright Rejection:** The directors may choose to accept some applications entirely and completely reject the remaining applications. The application money received for the rejected applications is fully refunded to the applicants.

2.  **Pro-Rata Allotment:** In this method, shares are allotted proportionately to all applicants. For instance, if applicants applied for 2 shares but only 1 could be allotted, it's a 1:2 ratio. The excess application money received from these applicants is usually adjusted first towards the amount due on allotment. If the excess application money is more than the allotment due, the remaining surplus can either be adjusted towards subsequent calls (treated as 'Calls in Advance') or refunded.

3.  **Combination Method:** This is the most common approach. Directors may reject some applications outright (and refund their money) and make a pro-rata allotment to the remaining applicants. The excess application money from the pro-rata allottees is then adjusted towards allotment and potentially future calls. This method balances equity among applicants with practical capital requirements.

From an accounting point of view, these situations primarily involve adjusting the Share Application Account, transferring appropriate amounts to Share Capital, Share Allotment, Calls in Advance, and Bank (for refunds). The objective is to accurately reflect the subscribed capital and manage cash flows during the issuance process.
longAnswerQuestions.answer50To75Words: When oversubscription occurs, companies typically choose from three allotment methods: outright rejection of some applications, pro-rata allotment to all applicants (adjusting excess application money towards allotment/calls), or a combination of both. Accounting involves transferring application money to share capital, adjusting for excess, and processing refunds, ensuring compliance and capital structure accuracy.

longAnswerQuestions.answer150Words:
A 'Preference Share' is a type of share that carries preferential rights over equity shares. These rights typically include a priority in receiving a fixed amount or rate of dividend before any dividend is paid to equity shareholders, and a priority in the repayment of capital during the winding up of the company. Different types of preference shares exist:

*   **Cumulative Preference Shares:** Unpaid dividends accumulate and must be paid before any dividend to equity shareholders.
*   **Non-Cumulative Preference Shares:** Unpaid dividends do not accumulate; the right to dividend for a year is lost if not paid in that year.
*   **Participating Preference Shares:** Entitle holders to a share in surplus profits after paying fixed preference dividend and equity dividend.
*   **Non-Participating Preference Shares:** Entitle holders only to the fixed preference dividend.
*   **Redeemable Preference Shares:** Can be bought back by the company after a certain period or event.
*   **Irredeemable Preference Shares:** Cannot be redeemed during the company's lifetime, only on winding up (though largely restricted by law now).

These different types allow companies to tailor their capital structure to specific financing needs and investor preferences.
longAnswerQuestions.answer200Words:
A 'Preference Share' is a class of share capital that holds specific advantages over ordinary (equity) shares. Its two primary preferential rights are:
1.  **Preferential right to Dividend:** Preference shareholders receive a dividend at a fixed rate or amount before any dividend is distributed to equity shareholders.
2.  **Preferential right to Repayment of Capital:** In the event of the company's winding up, preference shareholders are repaid their capital before equity shareholders.

Based on these rights, preference shares can be categorized into various types:
*   **Cumulative Preference Shares:** If dividends are not paid in a year due to insufficient profits, they accumulate and are paid in subsequent years before any equity dividend.
*   **Non-Cumulative Preference Shares:** Unpaid dividends do not accumulate; the right to receive dividends for a particular year is lost if not declared in that year.
*   **Participating Preference Shares:** These shares entitle the holder to a fixed preference dividend and also a share in the surplus profits of the company after equity shareholders have received a certain rate of dividend.
*   **Non-Participating Preference Shares:** Holders are only entitled to the fixed preference dividend and no share in surplus profits.
*   **Redeemable Preference Shares:** The company has the option to buy back or redeem these shares after a specified period or at a specific event.
*   **Irredeemable Preference Shares:** These shares cannot be redeemed during the company's lifetime (though the Companies Act, 2013, generally prohibits the issue of irredeemable preference shares, allowing only those redeemable within 20 years).

This variety enables companies to attract different types of investors with varying risk-return profiles.
longAnswerQuestions.answer50To75Words: A 'Preference Share' provides preferential rights over equity shares regarding fixed dividends and capital repayment on winding up. Types include Cumulative (dividends accumulate) vs. Non-Cumulative, Participating (share surplus profits) vs. Non-Participating, and Redeemable (can be bought back) vs. Irredeemable. These variations allow companies to meet diverse capital needs.

longAnswerQuestions.answer150Words: Provisions for 'Calls in Arrears' and 'Calls in Advance' are crucial for managing share capital. 'Calls in Arrears' occur when shareholders fail to pay due amounts on allotment or calls. The Companies Act and Table F of its Schedule I allow companies to charge interest, typically up to 10% per annum, on these unpaid amounts from the due date until payment. This incentivizes timely payments and compensates the company for delayed funds. Conversely, 'Calls in Advance' occur when shareholders voluntarily pay amounts not yet called up. As per Table F, companies are obligated to pay interest on these advance payments, typically up to 12% per annum, from the date of receipt until the call becomes due. This compensates shareholders for providing funds early and is treated as a current liability until adjusted against calls.
longAnswerQuestions.answer200Words:
The Companies Act, 2013, provides specific regulations concerning 'Calls in Arrears' and 'Calls in Advance', which are crucial for the efficient management of a company's share capital.

**Calls in Arrears:** This refers to the unpaid amounts on shares that have been duly called by the company but have not been received from the shareholders by the due date. The Articles of Association of a company usually contain provisions for dealing with such defaults, including the power to charge interest. If the Articles are silent, Table F of Schedule I to the Companies Act, 2013, stipulates that the company can charge interest on calls in arrears at a rate not exceeding 10% per annum. This interest is calculated for the period between the day fixed for payment and the date of actual payment. Accounting for calls in arrears involves debiting a 'Calls in Arrears Account' to reflect the unpaid balance.

**Calls in Advance:** This arises when shareholders voluntarily pay a part or the whole of the amount on shares that has not yet been called up by the company. The amount so received is treated as a liability for the company. As per Table F, if the Articles permit, the company is obligated to pay interest on calls in advance at a rate not exceeding 12% per annum. This interest is typically paid from the date of receipt of the advance until the date when the respective call money becomes due. The amount of calls in advance is credited to a 'Calls in Advance Account' and shown as 'Other Current Liabilities' in the balance sheet, not as part of paid-up capital. These provisions ensure fairness to both the company and its shareholders regarding timely payments and early contributions.
longAnswerQuestions.answer50To75Words: 'Calls in Arrears' are unpaid amounts on shares after a call is made; companies can charge interest (up to 10% p.a. as per Table F). 'Calls in Advance' are amounts paid by shareholders before a call is made; companies may pay interest (up to 12% p.a. as per Table F). These provisions ensure financial discipline and compensate parties for early/late payments, respectively.

longAnswerQuestions.answer150Words: 'Over subscription' occurs when applications for shares exceed the number offered for public subscription. This often indicates strong market confidence in the company. To handle this, directors can: 1) Reject some applications outright and refund money; 2) Make a 'pro-rata' allotment to all applicants, adjusting excess application money against allotment or future calls; or 3) Use a combination of rejection and pro-rata. Accounting involves transferring allotted application money to share capital, adjusting excesses to allotment/calls in advance, and refunding rejected amounts. 'Under subscription' happens when applications received are less than shares offered. If the subscription falls below the minimum subscription (90% of issued amount), the issue must be cancelled, and all application money refunded. Otherwise, shares are allotted for the subscribed quantity, and entries are made only for that number. Both situations require specific accounting adjustments to reflect the actual capital subscribed.
longAnswerQuestions.answer200Words:
'Over subscription' refers to a situation where the number of applications received from the public for a company's shares is more than the number of shares actually offered for subscription. This is generally a positive sign, reflecting strong investor demand. Accounting treatment for oversubscription involves several approaches:
1.  **Outright Rejection:** Applications for excess shares are completely rejected, and the entire application money received for these shares is refunded.
2.  **Pro-Rata Allotment:** Shares are allotted proportionately to all applicants. The excess application money received is adjusted towards the amount due on allotment, and if a balance remains, it can be adjusted against future calls (Calls in Advance) or refunded.
3.  **Combination:** A mix of outright rejection and pro-rata allotment is often used.

Journal entries will reflect the transfer of application money to share capital for allotted shares, adjustment to share allotment and calls in advance, and refunding amounts for rejected applications.

'Under subscription' occurs when the number of shares applied for is less than the number offered for subscription. In this scenario, the company can only allot shares up to the number subscribed. A critical condition here is the 'minimum subscription' requirement, which states that at least 90% of the issued amount must be subscribed for the allotment to be valid. If the minimum subscription is not achieved within a specified period (120 days from prospectus issue), the company cannot proceed with allotment and must refund the entire application money received, often with interest if delayed. If the minimum subscription is met, accounting entries are simply passed for the actual number of shares subscribed and allotted.

Otherwise, only subscribed shares are allotted. Accounting reflects actual subscriptions and adjustments.

The amount received as 'Securities Premium' when shares are issued above their nominal value is not a profit available for distribution as dividends. Its usage is strictly regulated by Section 52 of the Companies Act, 2013. A company can utilize the amount in the Securities Premium Account for specific purposes:
1.  **Issuing fully paid bonus shares:** Converting accumulated profits into share capital without requiring new cash from shareholders.
2.  **Writing off preliminary expenses:** Covering expenses incurred during the company's formation.
3.  **Writing off expenses, commission, or discount on issue of securities:** Absorbing costs related to issuing shares or debentures.
4.  **Paying premium on the redemption of preference shares or debentures:** Covering the additional amount paid when buying back or redeeming these securities.
5.  **Purchasing its own shares (buy-back):** Funding the repurchase of its own shares from the market. These uses are intended to strengthen the company's financial structure rather than fund daily operations or distribute profits.
longAnswerQuestions.answer200Words:
The 'Securities Premium Account' holds the premium amount collected when shares are issued at a price higher than their nominal (face) value. This amount is not considered a revenue profit and cannot be used for distributing dividends. Its utilization is governed by strict provisions under Section 52 of the Companies Act, 2013, to ensure capital protection and financial stability. The specific purposes for which a company can use the amount standing to the credit of the Securities Premium Account are:

1.  **For issuing fully paid bonus shares:** Companies can use this fund to convert their accumulated profits into bonus shares, distributed to existing shareholders without any cash payment from them.
2.  **For writing off preliminary expenses of the company:** These are expenses incurred during the formation and registration of the company.
3.  **For writing off the expenses of, or commission paid, or discount allowed on any issue of shares or debentures of the company:** This covers the costs associated with raising capital through the issuance of various securities.
4.  **For providing for the premium payable on the redemption of any redeemable preference shares or debentures of the company:** When redeemable preference shares or debentures are redeemed at a premium, the premium amount can be paid out of the Securities Premium Account.
5.  **For the purchase of its own shares (buy-back):** Companies can use the premium to finance the buy-back of their own shares, which can improve shareholder value and capital structure.

These restrictions ensure that the premium acts as a capital reserve, reinforcing the company's financial position rather than being used for operational expenses or profit distribution.

Its use is restricted by law for specific purposes: issuing bonus shares, writing off preliminary expenses, writing off share issue expenses/commission, paying premium on redemption of preference shares/debentures, or buy-back of shares. It strengthens the company's financial reserves.

Ordinarily, a company cannot issue shares at a discount (i.e., at a price less than their nominal value). However, the Companies Act, 2013, permits issue of shares at a discount in specific, limited circumstances:

1.  **Reissue of Forfeited Shares:** When shares are forfeited due to non-payment of calls, they can be reissued at a discount. However, the amount of discount allowed on reissue cannot exceed the amount that was originally received on the forfeited shares. This ensures that the company does not incur a capital loss on the reissued shares.
2.  **Sweat Equity Shares:** These are shares issued by a company to its directors or employees at a discount or for consideration other than cash, for providing know-how, making available intellectual property rights, or for value additions. This is an exception to the general rule against issuing shares at a discount, recognizing employees' valuable non-cash contributions. Strict conditions regarding resolution, market price, and class of employees apply to sweat equity issues.
longAnswerQuestions.answer200Words:
As a general rule, a company cannot ordinarily issue shares at a discount (i.e., at a price less than their nominal or par value). The Companies Act, 2013, aims to protect creditors by ensuring that shares are issued at least at their face value. However, there are specific, legally permissible conditions under which shares can be issued at a discount:

1.  **Reissue of Forfeited Shares:** When a company forfeits shares from shareholders who failed to pay calls, these forfeited shares can be reissued to new shareholders. While reissuing, the company is allowed to offer these shares at a discount. Crucially, the amount of discount allowed on the reissue of forfeited shares cannot exceed the amount that was originally received by the company on those specific forfeited shares. This ensures that the company recovers at least the full nominal value of the shares over their lifetime (original receipt + reissue price).

2.  **Issue of Sweat Equity Shares:** The Companies Act, 2013 (Section 54), allows a company to issue 'sweat equity shares' to its directors or employees at a discount or for consideration other than cash. This is permitted for providing know-how or making available rights in the nature of intellectual property rights or value additions. Stringent conditions apply for issuing sweat equity, including authorization by a special resolution, specifying the number of shares, current market price, consideration, and the class of employees. This provision acknowledges non-financial contributions from key personnel.

Apart from these two specific situations, issuing shares at a discount is generally prohibited.

Exceptions include: 1) Reissue of forfeited shares, where the discount cannot exceed the amount originally received on those shares. 2) Issue of 'Sweat Equity Shares' to directors or employees for their valuable non-cash contributions, subject to specific conditions. These exceptions are tightly regulated to protect investor interests.

longAnswerQuestions.answer150Words: 'Forfeiture of Shares' is the cancellation of shares by a company, authorized by its Articles of Association, when a shareholder fails to pay allotment or call money by the due date. It entails rescinding the contract of allotment and treating the amount already received on such shares as forfeited to the company. The accounting treatment involves reversing the original entries relating to the forfeited shares. The 'Share Capital Account' is debited with the called-up amount on forfeited shares. The respective unpaid call accounts (or 'Calls in Arrears Account') are credited with the unpaid amounts. The amount already received from the defaulter is credited to a 'Share Forfeiture Account'. If shares were issued at a premium and the premium was received, the Securities Premium Account is not affected. If premium was not received, it is debited during forfeiture. The balance in the Share Forfeiture Account is then added to Share Capital until reissue.
longAnswerQuestions.answer200Words:
The term 'Forfeiture of Shares' refers to the compulsory termination of membership and cancellation of shares by a company due to a shareholder's failure to pay calls or allotment money when due. This action is typically authorized by the company's Articles of Association, which usually follow the provisions of Table F of the Companies Act, 2013. Upon forfeiture, the amount already paid by the defaulting shareholder on those shares is retained by the company.

**Accounting Treatment on Forfeiture:**
When shares are forfeited, the accounting entries essentially reverse the original entries for the shares, except for any premium received. The objective is to remove the defaulted shares from the company's books and record the amount received on them as a capital receipt:

1.  **Debit Share Capital Account:** The Share Capital Account is debited with the 'called-up amount' per share on the forfeited shares, as this portion of capital is being cancelled.
2.  **Credit Unpaid Calls Accounts/Calls in Arrears Account:** The specific Share Allotment Account and/or Share Call Accounts (or a combined 'Calls in Arrears Account' if maintained) are credited with the respective unpaid amounts.
3.  **Credit Share Forfeiture Account:** The amount already paid by the defaulting shareholder on the forfeited shares (excluding any premium received, which remains untouched) is credited to a 'Share Forfeiture Account'. This account represents the capital gain from the forfeiture.

**Special Case - Shares Issued at Premium:**
*   If shares were issued at a premium and the premium amount has already been received, the Securities Premium Account is not debited at the time of forfeiture. The premium, once received, is considered earned.
*   If the premium amount was due but not received (e.g., unpaid with allotment money), then the Securities Premium Reserve Account is also debited with the unreceived premium amount during forfeiture.

The balance in the Share Forfeiture Account is shown as an addition to the 'Share Capital' in the balance sheet until these shares are reissued.
longAnswerQuestions.answer50To75Words: 'Forfeiture of Shares' means canceling shares for non-payment of calls, allowing the company to retain amounts already paid. Accounting involves debiting Share Capital (with called-up amount), crediting unpaid calls (or Calls in Arrears), and crediting the 'Share Forfeiture Account' with the amount received. If premium was unreceived, Securities Premium is also debited. This process reclaims defaulting shares for potential reissue.

mindmap.definition: According to Chief Justice Marshall, "a company is a person, artificial, invisible, intangible and existing only in the eyes of law. Being a mere creation of law, it possesses only those properties which the charter of its creation confers upon it, either expressly or as incidental to its very existence".
mindmap.explanation: A company is an association of persons contributing money or money's worth to a common inventory for a common purpose, recognized as a separate legal entity.
keyPoints: Corporate legal entity distinct from its members
mindmap.title: Company Form of Organisation

points.explanation: A company is formed and registered under specific laws, such as the Companies Act, 2013 in India, except for banking and insurance which have separate laws.
points.title: Body Corporate

points.explanation: A company has an identity separate from its members, allowing it to own property, enter contracts, and operate bank accounts in its own name.
points.title: Separate Legal Entity

points.explanation: The financial responsibility of members is limited to the unpaid amount of shares they hold or the guarantee they've given, protecting their private assets.
points.title: Limited Liability

points.explanation: A company's existence is not affected by changes in its membership; members may come and go, but the company continues until legally terminated.
points.title: Perpetual Succession

points.explanation: As an artificial person, a company requires an official seal to act as its signature on legal documents, making them binding.
points.title: Common Seal

points.explanation: Shares of a public limited company can be freely bought and sold without the company's or other members' consent, though Articles may prescribe the manner.
points.title: Transferability of Shares

points.explanation: Being a legal person, a company can enforce its contractual rights and can be legally challenged in its own name for breach of contract.
points.title: May Sue or be Sued

points.explanation: Liability of members is limited to the nominal value of shares held; if fully paid, no further liability.
points.title: Companies Limited by Shares

points.explanation: Liability of members is limited to the amount they undertake to contribute in case of company winding up; liability arises only then.
points.title: Companies Limited by Guarantee

points.explanation: No limit on members' liability; private property can be used to pay company debts if company assets are insufficient. Rarely found in India.
points.title: Unlimited Companies

points.explanation: A company which is not a private company and not a subsidiary of a private company.
points.title: Public Company

points.explanation: A company that restricts share transfer rights, has a minimum of 2 members (except OPC), and limits members to 200 (excluding employees).
points.title: Private Company

points.explanation: A company with only one person as a member, subject to specific conditions like being a natural Indian citizen and resident, and limits on capital and turnover.
points.title: One Person Company (OPC)

points.explanation: The amount contributed by shareholders to the company's capital.
points.title: Share Capital Definition

points.explanation: The maximum share capital a company is authorized to issue as per its Memorandum of Association (also Nominal or Registered Capital).
points.title: Authorised Capital

points.explanation: That part of the authorized capital which is actually issued to the public for subscription.
points.title: Issued Capital

points.explanation: The part of issued capital that has been actually subscribed by the public.
points.title: Subscribed Capital

points.explanation: The part of the subscribed capital that the company has formally demanded from shareholders.
points.title: Called-up Capital

points.explanation: The portion of the called-up capital that has been actually received from the shareholders.
points.title: Paid-up Capital

points.explanation: The portion of the subscribed capital which has not yet been called up by the company.
points.title: Uncalled Capital

points.explanation: A portion of uncalled capital reserved to be called only in the event of winding up of the company, available only for creditors.
points.title: Reserve Capital

points.explanation: Units into which the total share capital of a company is divided, representing fractional ownership.
points.title: Shares Definition

points.explanation: Shares that carry preferential rights regarding dividend payment and repayment of capital on winding up.
points.title: Preference Shares

points.explanation: Shares that do not enjoy preferential rights regarding dividend payment or capital repayment; entitled to residual profits and typically carry voting rights.
points.title: Equity Shares

points.explanation: The amount on shares can be collected in installments: application, allotment, and calls.
points.title: Instalment Collection

points.explanation: The company first issues a prospectus to invite the public to subscribe to its shares.
points.title: Issue of Prospectus

points.explanation: Prospective investors apply for shares along with application money, which must meet minimum subscription requirements (90% of issued amount).
points.title: Receipt of Applications

points.explanation: If minimum subscription is met and legal formalities are complete, the company proceeds to allot shares, sending allotment letters to successful applicants.
points.title: Allotment of Shares

points.explanation: Shares are issued at their nominal (face) value.
points.title: Issue at Par

points.explanation: Shares are issued at an amount more than their nominal value; the excess is premium, credited to Securities Premium Account.
points.title: Issue at Premium

points.explanation: Shares are issued at an amount less than their nominal value; generally prohibited except for reissued forfeited shares or sweat equity shares.
points.title: Issue at Discount

points.explanation: Initial journal entry for money received with application.
points.title: On Application

points.explanation: Entries for transferring application money to capital, refunding rejected applications, adjusting excess application money, and receiving allotment money.
points.title: On Allotment

points.explanation: Entries for call amount due and receipt of call amount, with specific naming conventions for calls.
points.title: On Calls

points.explanation: Unpaid amounts on allotment or calls. If maintained, 'Calls in Arrears Account' is debited. Interest not exceeding 10% p.a. may be charged as per Table F.
points.title: Calls in Arrears

points.explanation: Amounts received from shareholders for calls not yet made. Credited to 'Calls in Advance Account'. Interest not exceeding 12% p.a. may be paid as per Table F.
points.title: Calls in Advance

points.explanation: When applications for shares exceed the number offered. Directors can reject, make pro-rata allotment, or combine both. Excess application money is adjusted or refunded.
points.title: Over Subscription Accounting

points.explanation: When applications are less than shares offered. Allotment is confirmed only for subscribed shares. If minimum subscription (90%) is not met, the issue is cancelled and money refunded.
points.title: Under Subscription Accounting

points.explanation: Amount of premium is credited to Securities Premium Account, used for specific purposes: bonus shares, preliminary expenses write-off, share issue expenses write-off, premium on redemption, buy-back of shares.
points.title: Securities Premium Account Use

points.explanation: Company purchases assets from vendors and pays by issuing fully paid shares instead of cash. Number of shares depends on asset value and issue price (par/premium/discount).
points.title: Issue for Consideration other than Cash

points.explanation: Cancellation of shares for non-payment of allotment/call money. Share Capital is debited with called-up amount; unpaid calls/calls in arrears are credited; amount paid is credited to Share Forfeiture Account. Premium received is not reversed.
points.title: Forfeiture of Shares Accounting

points.explanation: Selling forfeited shares, which can be at a discount (not exceeding the forfeited amount). Discount is debited to Share Forfeiture Account. Balance in Share Forfeiture Account (profit on reissue) is transferred to Capital Reserve.
points.title: Reissue of Forfeited Shares Accounting

points.explanation: When a company purchases its own shares from existing shareholders, open market, etc. Financed by free reserves, securities premium, or proceeds of other issues. Requires special resolution and adherence to Companies Act conditions.
points.title: Buy-back of Shares

points.explanation: Company offers options to employees/directors to subscribe shares at lower than market value. Involves Grant, Vesting, Exercise, Vesting Period, Exercise Period, Exercise Price, Value of Option.
points.title: Employees Stock Option Plan (ESOP)

storyParts.speaker: Neil
storyParts.text: Kanishq, remember those early days in the garage, brainstorming ideas for KnowledgeCompass? We've come so far, now a successful EdTech corporation! It's incredible how much we've grown, especially our shareholder base.

storyParts.speaker: Kanishq
storyParts.text: Absolutely, Neil! Our journey perfectly illustrates the evolution of a business. We started small, but transitioning to a company form was crucial for our expansion. It's like building a solid foundation before reaching for the skies. The company's separate legal entity allowed us to operate independently of our personal identities, protecting us with limited liability, which was a huge draw for investors.

story.title: The Strategic Shift to a Company Form

storyParts.speaker: Neil
storyParts.text: Exactly. And the 'perpetual succession' aspect gives investors confidence that KnowledgeCompass will continue, regardless of who's on the Board or if a founder decides to step back. It's not just us anymore; it's an entity that exists in the eyes of the law. Speaking of which, our recent public issue of shares was a monumental task. The capital structure, from 'authorised' to 'paid-up capital', seemed so complex initially.

story.title: Foundational Pillars: Perpetual Succession and Capital Structure

storyParts.speaker: Kanishq
storyParts.text: It was, but our finance team nailed it. Understanding the difference between 'equity' and 'preference shares' was key to attracting diverse investors. Remember the overwhelming response we got? Applications poured in for far more shares than we offered – 'oversubscription' in action!

storyParts.speaker: Neil
storyParts.text: Yes, a fantastic problem to have! We had to decide between outright rejection, pro-rata allotment, or a mix. I recall the discussions on how to adjust that 'excess application money' towards allotment and even 'calls in advance' for some enthusiastic investors. The accounting for all those 'application', 'allotment', and 'call' stages felt like a complex dance.

storyParts.speaker: Kanishq
storyParts.text: And the meticulous record-keeping for 'calls in arrears'! Some shareholders, despite their best intentions, couldn't make timely payments. Our Articles of Association, thankfully, allowed us to charge interest on those arrears, ensuring financial discipline.

storyParts.speaker: Neil
storyParts.text: Indeed. And when some continued to default, we had to resort to 'forfeiture of shares' – a tough but necessary step to maintain capital integrity. It’s essentially cancelling their ownership due to non-payment. But then, we smartly 'reissued' those forfeited shares. The 'profit on reissue' went directly to 'Capital Reserve', strengthening our balance sheet.

story.title: The Challenge of Forfeiture and Reissue

storyParts.speaker: Kanishq
storyParts.text: It all ties back to the legal framework. Every step, from issuing shares at a 'premium' (which boosted our 'Securities Premium Account' for strategic uses like bonus shares or writing off expenses) to handling 'buy-back of shares' if we choose that route someday, is governed by the Companies Act. It’s fascinating how accounting translates legal requirements into financial reality.

story.title: Strategic Uses of Share Premium and Legal Framework

storyParts.speaker: Neil
storyParts.text: It truly is. From a small idea to managing complex share capital, understanding these accounting principles has been fundamental to KnowledgeCompass's growth into a robust corporation. It's not just about raising money; it's about building trust and ensuring long-term financial health for everyone involved.

story.title: Conclusion: Accounting as a Growth Catalyst
